content.query:
SET ANSI_NULLS ON
GO
SET QUOTED_IDENTIFIER ON
GO

CREATE TABLE [dbo].[NATO_Tweets1]
( 
	[id] bigint  NOT NULL,
	[created_at] DATETIME2(7)  NULL,
	[text] NVARCHAR(4000)  NULL,
	[lang] nvarchar(10)  NULL,
	[retweet_count] INT  NULL,
	[reply_count] INT  NULL,
	[like_count] INT  NULL,
	[quote_count] INT  NULL,
	[impression_count] INT  NULL
)
WITH
(
	DISTRIBUTION = HASH ( [id] ),
	CLUSTERED COLUMNSTORE INDEX
)
GO

SELECT DATEADD(second, (DATEPART(second, created_at) / 10) * 10, DATEADD(minute, DATEDIFF(minute, 0, created_at), 0)) AS IntervalStart,
       COUNT(*) AS Count
FROM [dbo].[NATO_Tweets1]
GROUP BY DATEADD(second, (DATEPART(second, created_at) / 10) * 10, DATEADD(minute, DATEDIFF(minute, 0, created_at), 0))
ORDER BY IntervalStart;

DROP TABLE [dbo].[NATO_Tweets1]
GO

SET ANSI_NULLS ON
GO
SET QUOTED_IDENTIFIER ON
GO

CREATE TABLE [dbo].[NATO_Tweets1]
( 
	[id] [bigint]  NOT NULL,
	[created_at] [datetime2](7)  NULL,
	[text] [nvarchar](4000)  NULL,
	[lang] [nvarchar](10)  NULL,
	[retweet_count] [int]  NULL,
	[reply_count] [int]  NULL,
	[like_count] [int]  NULL,
	[quote_count] [int]  NULL,
	[impression_count] [int]  NULL,
	[cleanText] [nvarchar](4000)
)
WITH
(
	DISTRIBUTION = HASH ( [id] ),
	CLUSTERED COLUMNSTORE INDEX
)
GO

source: !pip install azure-storage-file-datalake

# azureml-core of version 1.0.72 or higher is required
# azureml-dataprep[pandas] of version 1.1.34 or higher is required
from azureml.core import Workspace, Dataset

subscription_id = '57cd2ff8-9306-41d0-9cad-c2052a0a8381'
resource_group = 'Spring2023-TeamPendragon'
workspace_name = 'pendragon-ml'

workspace = Workspace(subscription_id, resource_group, workspace_name)

dataset = Dataset.get_by_name(workspace, name='NATO_Tweets')
df = dataset.to_pandas_dataframe()
df
## Remove @, #, links, and emoticons

# remove @s
df['text'] = df['text'].str.replace(r'@\w+\s*', '')

# remove hashtags
df['text'] = df['text'].str.replace(r'#\w+\s*', '')

# Remove links
import re
df['text'] = df['text'].apply(lambda x: re.sub(r'http\S+', '', x))

# drop rows where the 'text' column is an empty string
df = df.drop(df[df['text'] == ''].index)

# drop rows where the 'lang' column is not 'en'
df = df.drop(df[df['lang'] != 'en'].index)

# print the resulting dataframe
#df.head(10)

import re

# define a regex pattern to match emoticons
emoticon_pattern = re.compile("["
                              u"\U0001F600-\U0001F64F"  # emoticons
                              u"\U0001F300-\U0001F5FF"  # symbols & pictographs
                              u"\U0001F680-\U0001F6FF"  # transport & map symbols
                              u"\U0001F1E0-\U0001F1FF"  # flags (iOS)
                              "]+", flags=re.UNICODE)

# apply the regex pattern to the 'text' column to remove emoticons
df['text'] = df['text'].str.replace(emoticon_pattern, '')

# print the modified DataFrame
print(df['text'])
## Add a period to the end of text if one doesn't exist

# check if each string in 'text' column ends with a period
no_period_mask = ~df['text'].str.endswith('.')

# add period to the end of the strings that don't end with a period
df.loc[no_period_mask, 'text'] += '.'

# print the modified DataFrame
#print(df['text'])

# sort the DataFrame by the 'created_at' column
df = df.sort_values(by='created_at')
#df.head(10)

# Add required imports
import com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics
from com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics.Constants import Constants
from pyspark.sql.functions import col

# Name of the SQL Dedicated Pool or database where to run the query
# Database can be specified as a Spark Config or as a Constant - Constants.DATABASE
spark.conf.set("spark.sqlanalyticsconnector.dw.database", "SQLPoolTest")

# Read from a query
# Query can be provided either as an argument to synapsesql or as a Constant - Constants.QUERY
df = (spark.read
                     # Name of the SQL Dedicated Pool or database where to run the query
                     # Database can be specified as a Spark Config - spark.sqlanalyticsconnector.dw.database or as a Constant - Constants.DATABASE
                     .option(Constants.DATABASE, "SQLPoolTest")
                     # If `Constants.SERVER` is not provided, the `<database_name>` from the three-part table name argument
                     # to `synapsesql` method is used to infer the Synapse Dedicated SQL End Point.
                     .option(Constants.SERVER, "pendragon-synapse.sql.azuresynapse.net")
                     # Defaults to storage path defined in the runtime configurations
                     .option(Constants.TEMP_FOLDER, "abfss://pendragon@pendragon.dfs.core.windows.net/NotebookStaging")
                     # query from which data will be read
                     .option(Constants.QUERY, "select * from dbo.NATO_Tweets1")
                     .synapsesql()
#### Key Phrase Extraction, Named Entity Recognition, Sentiment Analysis

# Select sample size for testing

# Sort ascending by 'created_at'
from pyspark.sql.functions import desc

sorted_df = df.orderBy(desc("created_at"))


# select the first 20 records
first_20 = sorted_df.limit(20)
first_20.show()

import synapse.ml
from synapse.ml.cognitive import *
from pyspark.sql.functions import col
#print(dir(synapse.ml.cognitive))
linked_service_name = "CognitiveService1"
## Sentiment

sent = (TextSentiment()
    .setLinkedService(linked_service_name)
    .setOutputCol("sentiment")
    .setErrorCol("error"))
    
sent_output = sent.transform(first_20)
#display(sent.transform(first_20))
#display(sent.transform(first_20).select("text", col("sentiment")['document'].getItem("sentences").alias("sentences")))
sent_output.select("sentiment").show()

import json

# Extract the 'sentiment' column and convert it to JSON
json_output = sent_output.select("sentiment").toJSON().collect()

# Deserialize the JSON and extract the 'sentiment' field
sentiments = [json.loads(x)["sentiment"] for x in json_output]

output = []

# Print the 'sentiment' field for each row
for sentiment in sentiments:
    print(sentiment)
    output.append(sentiment['document']['sentiment'])

print(output)
## Entity Extraction

entity = (EntityDetector()
    .setLinkedService(linked_service_name)
    .setLanguage("en")
    .setOutputCol("replies")
    .setErrorCol("error"))

#display(entity.transform(df))
display(entity.transform(first_20).select("id", "text", col("replies")['document'].getItem("entities").alias("entities")))
## Key Phrase Extractor

keyPhrase = (KeyPhraseExtractor()
    .setLinkedService(linked_service_name)
    .setLanguageCol("lang")
    .setOutputCol("replies")
    .setErrorCol("error"))

display(keyPhrase.transform(first_20).select("text", col("replies")['document'].getItem("keyPhrases").alias("keyPhrases")))
## Named Entity Recognition

ner = (NER()
    .setLinkedService(linked_service_name)
    .setLanguageCol("lang")
    .setOutputCol("replies")
    .setErrorCol("error"))
display(ner.transform(first_20))
#display(ner.transform(first_20).select("text", "error, col("replies")['document'].getItem("entities").alias("entities")))

## Read from a query using Azure AD based authentication

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/synapse-analytics/spark/synapse-spark-sql-pool-import-export?tabs=python%2Cpython1%2Cscala2%2Cscala3%2Cscala4%2Cscala5

# Add required imports
import com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics
from com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics.Constants import Constants
from pyspark.sql.functions import col

# Name of the SQL Dedicated Pool or database where to run the query
# Database can be specified as a Spark Config or as a Constant - Constants.DATABASE
spark.conf.set("spark.sqlanalyticsconnector.dw.database", "SQLPoolTest")

# Read from a query
# Query can be provided either as an argument to synapsesql or as a Constant - Constants.QUERY
dfToReadFromQueryAsOption = (spark.read
                     # Name of the SQL Dedicated Pool or database where to run the query
                     # Database can be specified as a Spark Config - spark.sqlanalyticsconnector.dw.database or as a Constant - Constants.DATABASE
                     .option(Constants.DATABASE, "SQLPoolTest")
                     # If `Constants.SERVER` is not provided, the `<database_name>` from the three-part table name argument
                     # to `synapsesql` method is used to infer the Synapse Dedicated SQL End Point.
                     .option(Constants.SERVER, "pendragon-synapse.sql.azuresynapse.net")
                     # Defaults to storage path defined in the runtime configurations
                     .option(Constants.TEMP_FOLDER, "abfss://pendragon@pendragon.dfs.core.windows.net/NotebookStaging")
                     # query from which data will be read
                     .option(Constants.QUERY, "select * from dbo.NATO_Tweets1")
                     .synapsesql()
)

dfToReadFromQueryAsArgument = (spark.read
                     # Name of the SQL Dedicated Pool or database where to run the query
                     # Database can be specified as a Spark Config - spark.sqlanalyticsconnector.dw.database or as a Constant - Constants.DATABASE
                     .option(Constants.DATABASE, "SQLPoolTest")
                     # If `Constants.SERVER` is not provided, the `<database_name>` from the three-part table name argument
                     # to `synapsesql` method is used to infer the Synapse Dedicated SQL End Point.
                     .option(Constants.SERVER, "pendragon-synapse.sql.azuresynapse.net")
                     # Defaults to storage path defined in the runtime configurations
                     .option(Constants.TEMP_FOLDER, "abfss://pendragon@pendragon.dfs.core.windows.net/NotebookStaging")
                     # query from which data will be read
                     .synapsesql("select * from dbo.NATO_Tweets1")
)

# Show contents of the dataframe
dfToReadFromQueryAsOption.show()
dfToReadFromQueryAsArgument.show()
df = dfToReadFromQueryAsArgument
## Text Analytics
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/synapse-analytics/machine-learning/tutorial-text-analytics-use-mmlspark

import synapse.ml
from synapse.ml.cognitive import *
from pyspark.sql.functions import col
linked_service_name = "CognitiveService1"

# Create a dataframe that's tied to it's column names
df = spark.createDataFrame([
  ("Hello World",),
  ("Bonjour tout le monde",),
  ("La carretera estaba atascada. Haba mucho trfico el da de ayer.",),
  ("",),
  ("",),
  (":) :( :D",)
], ["text",])

# Run the Text Analytics service with options
language = (LanguageDetector()
    .setLinkedService(linked_service_name)
    .setTextCol("text")
    .setOutputCol("language")
    .setErrorCol("error"))

# Show the results of your text query in a table format
display(language.transform(df))
## Remove special characters

from pyspark.sql.functions import regexp_replace

# remove special characters from text column
df = df.withColumn("text", regexp_replace(df["text"], "[^a-zA-Z0-9\\s]", ""))

df_text = df.select('text')

# show resulting dataframe
df_text.show()
## Write back to SQLPoolTest dbo.NATO_Tweets1 table using Azure AD based authentication

# Write using AAD Auth to internal table
# Add required imports
import com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics
from com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics.Constants import Constants

# Configure and submit the request to write to Synapse Dedicated SQL Pool
# Sample below is using AAD-based authentication approach; See further examples to leverage SQL Basic auth.
(df.write
 # If `Constants.SERVER` is not provided, the `<database_name>` from the three-part table name argument
 # to `synapsesql` method is used to infer the Synapse Dedicated SQL End Point.
 .option(Constants.SERVER, "pendragon-synapse.sql.azuresynapse.net")
 # Like-wise, if `Constants.TEMP_FOLDER` is not provided, the connector will use the runtime staging directory config (see section on Configuration Options for details).
 .option(Constants.TEMP_FOLDER, "abfss://pendragon@pendragon.dfs.core.windows.net/NotebookStaging")
 # Choose a save mode that is apt for your use case.
 # Options for save modes are "error" or "errorifexists" (default), "overwrite", "append", "ignore".
 # refer to https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/sql-data-sources-load-save-functions.html#save-modes
 .mode("overwrite")
 # Required parameter - Three-part table name to which data will be written
 .synapsesql("SQLPoolTest.dbo.NATO_Tweets1"))

# Add required imports
import com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics
from com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics.Constants import Constants
from pyspark.sql.functions import col

# Name of the SQL Dedicated Pool or database where to run the query
# Database can be specified as a Spark Config or as a Constant - Constants.DATABASE
spark.conf.set("spark.sqlanalyticsconnector.dw.database", "SQLPoolTest")

# Read from a query
# Query can be provided either as an argument to synapsesql or as a Constant - Constants.QUERY
df = (spark.read
                     # Name of the SQL Dedicated Pool or database where to run the query
                     # Database can be specified as a Spark Config - spark.sqlanalyticsconnector.dw.database or as a Constant - Constants.DATABASE
                     .option(Constants.DATABASE, "SQLPoolTest")
                     # If `Constants.SERVER` is not provided, the `<database_name>` from the three-part table name argument
                     # to `synapsesql` method is used to infer the Synapse Dedicated SQL End Point.
                     .option(Constants.SERVER, "pendragon-synapse.sql.azuresynapse.net")
                     # Defaults to storage path defined in the runtime configurations
                     .option(Constants.TEMP_FOLDER, "abfss://pendragon@pendragon.dfs.core.windows.net/NotebookStaging")
                     # query from which data will be read
                     .option(Constants.QUERY, "select * from dbo.NATO_Tweets1")
                     .synapsesql()

# sort dataframe by date column in ascending order
sorted_df = df.orderBy(col("impression_count").desc())

# show sorted dataframe
sorted_df.show()

# select the first 20 records
first_20 = sorted_df.limit(20)
first_20.show()

from pyspark.sql.functions import collect_list, concat_ws

# concatenate strings in "text" column into a single string
concatenated_string = first_20.agg(concat_ws("", collect_list("text"))).collect()[0][0]

print(concatenated_string)

from pyspark import SparkContext
sc = SparkContext.getOrCreate()

input_string = concatenated_string

def remove_emoji(text):
    return text.encode('ascii', 'ignore').decode('ascii')
result_string = remove_emoji(input_string)

words_rdd = sc.parallelize(result_string.split())
filtered_words_rdd = words_rdd.filter(lambda word: not word.startswith("#"))
result_string = " ".join(filtered_words_rdd.collect())

words_rdd = sc.parallelize(result_string.split())
filtered_words_rdd = words_rdd.filter(lambda word: not word.startswith("@"))
result_string = " ".join(filtered_words_rdd.collect())

words_rdd = sc.parallelize(result_string.split())
filtered_words_rdd = words_rdd.filter(lambda word: not word.startswith("&"))
result_string = " ".join(filtered_words_rdd.collect())

words_rdd = sc.parallelize(result_string.split())
filtered_words_rdd = words_rdd.filter(lambda word: not word.startswith("https"))
result_string = " ".join(filtered_words_rdd.collect())

print(result_string)

#!pip install openai
import openai


openai.api_type = "azure"
openai.api_base = "https://querystructureddata.openai.azure.com/"
openai.api_version = "2022-12-01"
openai.api_key = "c607bf2bba454302b492ba369efe54f6"
p = 'Provide a summary of the text below that captures the main idea. ' + result_string
p

#Note: The openai-python library support for Azure OpenAI is in preview.
import os
import openai
openai.api_type = "azure"
openai.api_base = "https://querystructureddata.openai.azure.com/"
openai.api_version = "2022-12-01"
openai.api_key = "c607bf2bba454302b492ba369efe54f6"

# query = input("Enter your query in natural language: ")

response = openai.Completion.create(
  engine="SumTest",
  prompt = p,
  temperature=0.3,
  max_tokens=250,
  top_p=1,
  frequency_penalty=0,
  presence_penalty=0,
  best_of=1,
  stop=None)

response
p = 'Perform key phrase extraction on the following text. ' + result_string
